`hello world`

My name is [**Ed Rubin**](bio.html), and I'm an assistant professor in the [**Department of Economics**](https://economics.uoregon.edu) at the [**University of Oregon**](https://www.uoregon.edu).

I research the <b><font color="#FFC107">economics</font></b> of the <b><font color="#FFC107">environment</font></b> and <b><font color="#FFC107">inequality/discrimination</font></b>.

More broadly, I aim to answer policy-relevant questions about <b><font color="#BDBDBD">social equity</font></b> and <b><font color="BDBDBD">environmental quality</font></b> using tools from <b><font color="#BDBDBD">economics</font></b>, <b><font color="#BDBDBD">econometrics</font></b>, <b><font color="#BDBDBD">statistics</font></b> and <b><font color="#BDBDBD">data science</font></b>.

More specifically, my research looks at <b><font color="#BDBDBD">how individuals respond to environmental regulation and environmental quality</font></b>—and how these responses may render policy inefficient and/or unequal.

I love data, (beautiful) graphs/maps, the outdoors, [bikes](https://www.instagram.com/p/CRyaIAwnwFV/?utm_source=ig_web_copy_link), [photography](https://www.instagram.com/edwardarubin/), and [people](https://www.instagram.com/p/CdCiAtbNNSQ/?utm_source=ig_web_copy_link). I enjoy consuming pizza, phở, tacos, coffee, and computational power. I'm a bunch of other things too.

In a few other professional things, I

- with [**friends**](https://tweeds.io/about/), started [**TWEEDS**](https://tweeds.io)—The Workshop in Environmental Economics and Data Science,
- help run [**OSWEET**](https://edrub.in/osweet.html), an online workshop where graduate students and early-career faculty can present their work on environmental, energy, and transportation economics (and receive constructive feedback),
- co-wrote a textbook on [**Data Science and Public Policy**](https://link.springer.com/book/10.1007/978-3-030-71352-2).

Please look around and/or [contact me](contact.html).
